title: Effect of Astaxanthin on the Patients With Alzheimer Disease
description_brief: This study adapts a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial, to exam the possible benefit of Astaxanthin on Alzheimer disease. The enrolled Alzheimer patients will take Astaxanthin or placebo for 1 year. We will follow up Mini-Mental State Examination, Cognitive Ability Screening Instrument, Clinical Dementia Rating, and Neuropsychiatric Inventory at the end of the study.
description_detailed: This study aims to examine the benefit of Astaxanthin as adjuvant therapy for Alzheimer's disease.
explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is astaxanthin, a dietary carotenoid with potent antioxidant/anti-inflammatory and putative neuroprotective properties, i.e., a small molecule nutraceutical rather than a biologic. citeturn0search4

Act: The trial tests astaxanthin versus placebo for 1 year with cognitive endpoints (MMSE, CASI, CDR) and neuropsychiatric inventory—indicating the primary intent is to improve/maintain cognition rather than to deliver a targeted anti-amyloid or anti-tau biologic. Therefore it fits the 'cognitive enhancer' category. citeturn0search1turn0search5

Supporting nuance: Preclinical/animal studies report astaxanthin can reduce oxidative stress, neuroinflammation and in some models lower amyloid and tau markers, suggesting possible disease-modifying potential in animals; but the human trials and the described protocol aim at cognitive/neuropsychiatric outcomes rather than a pathway-specific anti-amyloid/tau mechanism. This creates some ambiguity, but classification should follow the trial's measured outcomes and mechanism (antioxidant/neuroprotective) — hence 'cognitive enhancer'. citeturn0search2turn0search3

Reflect: Conclusion checked—astaxanthin is a small-molecule carotenoid supplement tested for cognitive benefit in AD patients; it is not a monoclonal antibody or vaccine (so not a disease-targeted biologic), nor is it described as a small-molecule drug designed to inhibit a specific AD pathological enzyme/pathway (so not clearly a disease-targeted small molecule). The best-fit category is 'cognitive enhancer'. citeturn0search4turn0search1
explanation_agent: Reason: The intervention is astaxanthin, a small‑molecule xanthophyll carotenoid with well‑described antioxidant (and secondary anti‑inflammatory / neuroprotective) actions — the mechanism relevant to Alzheimer's is reduction of oxidative stress and related pathways. citeturn1search4turn1search0

Act: The described trial (Effect of Astaxanthin on the Patients With Alzheimer Disease, NCT05015374) tests astaxanthin versus placebo with cognitive and neuropsychiatric endpoints over 1 year — the protocol and drug identity indicate a nutraceutical antioxidant approach rather than an amyloid‑ or tau‑targeted biologic/small‑molecule enzyme inhibitor, so the most specific CADRO match is oxidative stress. citeturn0search1turn0search5

Reflect: Reviews and preclinical studies also report anti‑inflammatory, anti‑apoptotic, synaptic/neurogenic effects and occasional reductions in amyloid/tau markers in animal models; these secondary mechanisms create some overlap with CADRO categories F (Inflammation) and M (Synaptic plasticity/Neuroprotection), but astaxanthin’s primary, well‑characterized bioactivity is antioxidant/anti‑oxidative‑stress — therefore G) Oxidative Stress is the best single‑category assignment. citeturn1search3turn0search2

Web search results (key sources used): 1) Trial record for 'Effect of Astaxanthin on the Patients With Alzheimer Disease' (NCT05015374) — trial design, endpoints, intervention (astaxanthin vs placebo). citeturn0search1turn0search5 2) 'Exploring astaxanthin: a comprehensive review on its pharmacokinetics properties and neuroprotective potential' — describes potent antioxidant, anti‑inflammatory and BBB penetration / neuroprotection. citeturn1search4 3) 'Neuroprotective and Neurotrophic Effects of Astaxanthin on the Brain' — review highlighting antioxidant and anti‑inflammatory neuroprotective mechanisms. citeturn1search0 4) 'Dietary Astaxanthin: ... brain aging and adult neurogenesis' — notes antioxidant and anti‑inflammatory actions and effects on neurogenesis pathways. citeturn1search2 5) Preclinical study examples showing reductions in amyloid/tau markers and improvements in AD models (supporting secondary disease‑modifying signals in animals). citeturn0search2turn0search6
